results.title: Discovery
results.brief_description: A document in sound and image, with minimal narration, of northern Indian urban culture. Recording the gestural qualities of everyday life. The film-makers hope to find evidence of a divinity which animates all the drama and movement of a modern Indian city. The fine score is composed from a dynamic mix of field recordings.

results.title: Discovering perspective
results.creator_credit: Jerry Samuelson, Paul Burnford and Film Associates of California
results.brief_description: We live in a world of depth and distance, which is called perspective. In drawing or painting on a flat surface, there are several ways in which to create the appearance of perspective: by overlapping and the placement of objects and lines, use of color, making objects clear or indistinct, and varying the size of objects.

results.title: Disasters: national preparedness
results.creator_credit: Greg Reading, Peter Johnston, Natural Disasters Organisation (Australia) and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Shows the work of the Natural Disasters Organisation. A simulated exercise to show the co-ordination of relief lines involves a cyclone and an earthquake in separate locations in Western Australia.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Greg Reading, Peter Johnston, Natural Disasters Organisation (Australia) and Film Australia

results.title: Disappearing world revisited. Ep. 3
results.creator_credit: Kathryn Ferguson and Granada Television International
results.brief_description: This three part series made for the Discovery Channel draws its material from the landmark Disappearing World documentary series produced by Granada Television in the 1970s. With each of over fifty episodes supervised by an anthropologist, the series set out to record the way of life of indigenous peoples around the world whose traditional cultures were under threat. Each episode of “Disappearing world revisited” briefly recaps three of these original stories then provides a short overview of the situation of the tribal peoples today. The three stories revisited in Episode 3 are: 1. “Kataragama”: In Sri Lanka, worshippers of the god Kataragama perform extreme feats of devotion. 2. “The Kirghiz of Afghanistan” Looks at the harsh life of the Kirghiz who live in the Pamir region of Afghanistan on the highest plateau in the world at 15,000 feet between the closed borders of Pakistan, China and Russia. 3. “Embera: The End of the Road”: The traditional life of the river people of Colombia is threatened by a new major highway, and exploitation by traders. Presented by Andy Kershaw.

results.title: Disappearing world revisited. Ep. 2
results.creator_credit: Kathryn Ferguson and Granada Television International
results.brief_description: This three part series made for the Discovery Channel draws its material from the landmark Disappearing World documentary series produced by Granada Television in the 1970s. With each of over fifty episodes supervised by an anthropologist, the series set out to record the way of life of indigenous peoples around the world whose traditional cultures were under threat. Each episode of “Disappearing world revisited” briefly recaps three of these original stories then provides a short overview of the situation of these people today. The three tribal peoples revisited in Episode 2 are: 1. Sakkudei: Living deep in the jungles of Sumatra, the Sakkudei are nevertheless forced by the Indonesian government to conform with 20th century society. 2. Dervishes of Kurdistan: Dervish tribesmen living in the mountainous frontier of Iran and Iraq perform feats of self mutilation to prove their devotion to Islam. 3. Masai Women: Focuses on the expectations placed on woman from the Masai tribe from the East African Rift Valley of Kenya once they reach child bearing age. Presented by Andy Kershaw.

results.title: Dirty rotten scoundrels (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Frank Oz, Bernard Williams and Orion Pictures Corporation
results.brief_description: In Beaumont-sur-mer on the French Riviera, Lawrence Jamison (Michael Caine), a suave stylish con man who is an expert at extracting jewels from rich, married women must find a way to deal with crass new competition in the person of Freddy Benson (Steve Martin), a small time scam artist who tells tragic tales about his grandma to secure a few francs from almost anyone! Eventually they decide to compete and make a wager that whoever cannot swindle a certain naive soap heiress (Glenne Headly) for $50,000 must leave the French Riviera hunting ground. A remake of the 1964 “Bedtime stories”.

results.title: People count
results.creator_credit: Australian Bureau of Statistics and Visual Media
results.brief_description: Tells the story of the 1981 Census and shows how information from the Census can help people make informed decisions about most things that touch their lives. Also explains how the Bureau of Statistics turns the personal details of nearly fifteen million people into purely anonymous statistics. No other credits available.

results.title: Dirty pretty things
results.creator_credit: Stephen Frears, Robert Jones, Tracey Seaward, BBC Film Unit and Miramax Films
results.brief_description: An illegal immigrant in urban London, Okwe, is working as a cab driver and doing the nightshift as a hotel receptionist (Chiwetel Ejiofor). He is sharing a flat with one of the hotel’s maids, Senay, (Audrey Tautou’s first English speaking role) who is also an illegal but dreams of escaping to live in America. Initially the film is more a character study of the pair always living in fear of deportation and struggling with poverty but soon develops into a thriller as one night, a gruesome discovery in room 510’s blocked toilet, leads to blackmail and involvement with London’s sordid underworld. Cast includes Sergi Lopez, Benedict Wong and Sophie Okonedo.

results.title: Dirty Harry
results.creator_credit: Don Siegel, Warner Bros Pictures and Malpaso Company
results.brief_description: Harry Callaghan is a tough, streetwise San Francisco cop whom they call Dirty Harry. In this classic film, you will see why. You will also see why Clint Eastwood’s reputation is secure. No other actor can match his presence. He is magnetising in his portrayal as the shoot-first-ask-questions-later law enforcer who must hunt a psychotic roof-top killer who has slain two people and has kidnapped a girl and threatens to suffocate her if his ransom demands are not met. Harry will get him… one way or the other… no matter what the “system” prescribes. Moody cinematography and stunning location filming propel the story and capitalise upon Eastwood’s commanding presence. Watch this film and ask yourself: Do you feel lucky?

results.title: Dirty deeds
results.creator_credit: David Caesar, Deborah Balderstone, Bryan Brown and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: David Caesar takes an irreverent swipe at the gangster genre with this film set in the milieu of the 60s crime scene in Australia, which owes much to the spirit of more contemporary crime films such as Guy Richie’s “Lock, Stock and two smoking barrels”. It is 1969 and the criminal underbelly of Sydney’s King’s Cross has proven to be a lucrative business for notorious crime boss, Barry Ryan (Bryan Brown). His small-scale local operation is threatened however when the American Mafia catch wind of Barry’s profitable dealings and decide to muscle their way in. The scene is set for a David and Golliath battle between dodgy crooks and dodgier crooks! Caesar’s script is based partly on truth, particularly events surrounding the infiltration of the American mafia into Australian crime. “Dirty Deeds” uses this as a basis however to comment on the subsequent Americanization of Australian culture, while playfully poking fun at the Aussie laissez faire attitude vs American corporate efficiency. Cast also includes: Toni Collette, Sam Neill, John Goodman, Sam Worthington, Kestie Morassi, William McInnes.
